q.q: What are some cool ways you can substitute an 11th chord into a progression?

q.a: where i come from, "11" usually only is used on minor chords. i don't quite see how your example adds up. in C assuming you mean 1,3,5,7,9,11 (which mostly no one would do, i'm not sure if you meant#11? or is it a minor chord all along?) and then you add a 6, that doesn't really make Fmaj9. anyway, it's not too good to think about it this way. just use the notes you need to support the melody, then afterwards you can argue about what to put on the page. Sounds like you are a bit goal oriented on using the number 11 on the page, and that might not be a good way to look at it. A useful example of something that might end up being called "11" is let's say it's the key of C, melody note is G, and it's a Dmin7 chord. in reality you might play C,F,G(notes) in the chord, and call it Dmin11 if you want. Or let's say you are in the key of Cmin and it's just a Cmin vamp for a while and you've got a melody that is focusing on the F note. then you might use F,D,Bb notes in your chord, with the Eb tucked in there too. or more likely even, oscilating between a Bb triad and Eb triad in the chord. similarly in the relative major version of that, in the key of Eb, you might see a F note on a Cmin chord, and the chordal player will play Bb triad (over C) first, before swicthing to the Eb triad (Cmin7). all these things might be called 11. but to be honest it's not too necessary to really use the number 11 when talking about chords, it's kind of confusing, and the way it's taught as a stack of 3rds up to 11 is a bit confusing and does not really represent most musical realities. because a full stack up to 11 would have 6 notes, and most chords have less than 6 notes, so most chords being called '11' wont really have all the notes. also stacking it from the bottom up is not something that normally happens in reality outside of a music textbook or class. usually when you see 11 on the page it just means that the melody note is a 4th above the bass. and the remaining notes are chosen sensibly for the situation. i hope that makes sense
q.q: I get you can incorporate them however you want into your own writing... but what about when playing with others? For example, if the chart of a song has a IV chord, would a I11 chord work over the IV in most situations? If you throw a major 6th into a I11 chord, that would esssentially make it a IVmaj9.

q.a: in time, 2s are very powerful. that's because 2 is a low number, and almost anything can work in 2s. breathing (in, out) walking (left right). the next number is 3, which is also low, and very simple, and that is a prominent number in musical rhythms as well. 4 is just 2 2s. so when something is in 4, it's just 2s. 2 groups of 2. and then 2 groups of 2 groups of 2 (2 bars.) and then 2 groups of 2 groups of 2 groups of 2 (4 bars.) that's why music works so well in 4, 8, and 16 bar sections. you're just hearing 2s in 2s in 2s etc

q.a: i used to worry about different fonts for everything, but that became not only a waste of time, but also distracting from a viewing standpoint. i ultimately made a decision to actually use the default font for everything. it gave me a lot of creative clarity, and greater efficiency. i learned it's better to focus on your strong points, and don't worry about things that are not your strong points. i don't make my own fonts, and i don't have access to a large font libary, so this would not be a strong point. by religiously using the default font only, i found that i could instantly put all my focus on things that are my strong points -- positioning, angles, motion, and timing, and of course the content of the text

q.a: it's more like write/research/write (including writing the exact notes and chords of all the parts with singing).... phase 2 is make a plan for how to execute the thing and gather all the elements needed.... then record a temp narration with proper timing including any singing... then build the actual visuals over that.... then record the final narration... re-allign the timing of the graphics to fit the new narration.... record the final music  and vocals for the parts with singing.... then finally do all the other instrumental music and sounds that fills the rest of the video.... then start doing troubleshooting lists and fixing everything on the list until you have smaller and smaller lists until the things to fix are so small that you don't care

Just feel it, man.  Fuck the process.5.  Listen to more records, close the Real Book.

q.a: there are many different variations of the commandments, and they have changed over time, but i did a lot of research into it in order to build the list i used. from what i found, it seemed that that commandment really (originally) meant that you're not supposed to want stuff that you are not supposed to have. the neighbor part seemed to have been added later, or only in some versions, if i remember correctly. at least that is the way it looked when i was doing the research. keep in mind this was a very long video and i don't exactly remember the details but i do remember that i did quite a bit of research just for that one screen that lasts maybe 1 second, and i was very careful to try to reflect the actual commandments as accurately as possible while still making it a rowdy fun time. when in doubt i tried to go for the older/original meaning, because there are so many different variations

q.a: ah, you are suggesting that i pursue the 'perfect' tuning, instead of using equal temperment tuning. this sounds like a righteous idea, but i have to tell you that i embarked on a viscious mission (in about january 2011 i believe) to get to the bottom of this situation. i set out to get a perfect tuning that at least worked in 1 key. after many hours (days? i don't remember) of experimentation, what i found surprised me. you actually can't do it. even to play within 1 key, you need to compromise. let me see if i can explain it: start by tuning a C chord properly (so that the E is a true harmony with C, and the G is a true 5th from C.) So let's get our F, that's gonna be a true 5th down from C, right? now A should be a pure major third above F, for sure. and B should surely be a pure major 3rd above G. now what should D be? you would assume that it would be a pure ninth from C (i.e. the frequency times 9 and then divided back down the octaves) which is good for the G chord also because it will be a 5th away from G. looks great, so now you've got C, D, E, F, G, A, B. but what you find next might come as a shock. D minor sounds like a nightmare. because D to A is supposed to be a 5th and now it is a very very wrong 5th. because you tuned your A to be a harmonically pure major 3rd away from F. no matter how you slice it, you inevitably run into the same argument where a 3rd needs to be a purely harmonic 3rd, but also needs to be a series of 5ths. i juggled the possibilities all around for at least a day, and i was completely stunned to find out that the essence of music, and specifically the way the "secondary" notes (let's say in a major key, the secondary notes are D, F, A, and also G, and the primary notes are C,E,G. that's right, G is both, the universe is a love paradox, get used to it) the secondary notes need equal tempered tuning to work right. there are surely many different ways to look at this and i made up the primary and secondary classifications for this example, but the point is that there will always be overlap. you will never have 2 exclusive sets of notes. it stems from the fact that the D note needs to be able to relate to G, but also needs to relate to the A, but the A also needs to relate to the F, and the F also definitely needs to relate to the C. now you might say "ok, tune them differently depending on what chords you're using." but that really doesn't work right, because music needs all these notes to coexist. you're not going to just expect that Dmin and Fmaj will never need to blend together with the A held over. or that Dmin and Gmaj will never need to blend together with the D held over. At the end of this mind exploding journey, i basically found that it seems to be summed up perfectly in 2 chords. Cmaj, and like any combination of D,F,A, and G perhaps with G in the bass. in that 'secondary' chord, all in one moment, (which is the 'less' stable of the 2 chords when they are used in a musical context) that chord encapsulates the dual nature of the way these harmonies are working. is the F in that chord supposed to relate mainly to the C? or is it supposed to relate to the D in a pure minor third? and similarly, is the D supposed to relate to the G? the answer is, all 3 of these relationships are supposed to hold together. but this is mathematically impossible to happen exactly. so the entire essence of that Dmin, or 5dom7(sus if you like?) whatever, 'secondary' chord, the entire essence of that chord is that it contains different relationships that have to all sound like they work and yet they could never all 3 work exactly. the chord needs compromise in order to work. perhaps that is why it feels like the secondary chord or the 'less stable' or the 'i'm just waiting to go back to C' chord. realizing this changed me, because i was always told that equal tempered tuning was mainly used as a compromise to play in all 12 keys. but what i realized is you actually need it just to play in 1 key. like, just to play a 1 and a 2min. just to play the most basic essence of a key and have it work with itself. it really made me appreciate that 'secondary' chord (Dmin, G, etc) the D to F and the D to G relationship on kind of an earth shattering spiritual level, it's like the damn thing has heartbreak built right in. what you think you are hearing is the d to f relationship and the d to g relationship and the f to c relationthip, etc, all at the same time, when really it could never be, at least not exactly. but it is close enough to feel it. basically ever since this experiment i have had a wildly new appreciation for how and why music works, on an even more 'human' level than i expected. and i never questioned equal tempered tuning again
q.q: i understand that you don't want searching for better and better sounds all the time to get in your way of just writing and recording, but don't you want to transcend a lot of cultural elements that have no distinct purpose to you that you were born into? like approximating the way notes fit together in harmony by using the equal temperament tuning? i dont mean like retune your keyboards, but when talking about microtonal music, i usually tend to think of tuning chords to the harmonic series, rather than the piano. i just hope you actively do that when you can instead of using an easier way all the time to get more content finished. after all you do seem like quite the creativity purist. hell im sure you've thought about it tho. nevermind. you don't need to respond to this im just rambling cause i get triggered when you say no to microtonal music. ur right, splitting half notes in half again doesn't really make that much sense

q.a: "6 figure income" means your yearly income (money) has 6 digits. so like 500,000 dollars a year is a "6 figure income." 5,000,000 dollars a year would be a 7 figure income. that lyric is from the song new canaan, which tells the story of an aimless exploratory trip to a random town accessible via the New York transit system. one of the most immediately notable traits of the town is that it seems to be a really rich town. a '6-figure income town' would be a town where people with a 6-figure income might live. 12-figures is surely an exaggeration, but it seemed to be the number that fit the best in the song at that time

q.a: it's an instrument randomization system i came up with in 2015. the trick is, you pick a random instrument, and then you are responsible for finding where in the song it fits, and what to do on it. for example, you might pick something that seems all wrong for the song, and you might say "oh no, that's all wrong for this song." but if you start searching through the song, bar by bar, you will find just the right spot to put it. and then when listening to it, it sounds like a really fresh choice, and it fits the spot because you found where it fits, but the listener might think you went and found the instrument based on what would fit in that spot, but you actually picked the instrument first and then found the spot. life hack. turns out this is the only way i can get anything done now

q.a: i'm randomizing from a long list of songs which includes songs where the writing is finished and where writing is not finished. whichever one i pick, i have to finish the writing, and record it. this is a system i started to use last year except this year i have added an extra twist which is that i tell myself that i technically don't have to release it, but i do have to finish it and record it. this is very important because it prevents me from getting cold feet about the selection, and helps me carry on and record it and not 'blame the selection.' this creates somewhat of a paradox because if i follow through on the recording, i'm gonna find a way to make it good, and will end up posting it in the end. but for some reason it really helps to at least pretend thst i'm not required to release it. this enables me to freely experiment on trying to make the best of what might seem like a weak selection. for example, when 'california' came up, my first reaction was 'oh no, not another weed song. people are gonna think all my songs are about weed' and i probably would have chickened out on the selection and then the entire credibility of the random system would collapse. but if i'm allowed to just 'try' recording it to see if i can make it good, it removes the pressure. and allows me to try making it the best i can make it, without stressing that it's the wrong selection. like i said, this strategy is a huge paradox in many ways but it seems to work

q.q: I know you already have answered a few questions on here about defining music, and I like your thoughts on it. Really, it doesn't matter what the definition of music is. It has no clear definition, and yet it still exists, people make it and people listen to it and buy it. There's lots of different ways people have defined music.. some have given really simplified answers. Edgard Varese has one of the most famous definitions of music as being  "organized sound." Frank Zappa said "a composer is a guy who goes around forcing his will on unsuspecting air molecules, often with the assistance of unsuspecting musicians." Barney Childs' definition is that "A piece of music is simply a chunk of time you are paying attention to with your ears." Others have given definitions that are more abstract, like Beethoven ("Music is the one incorporeal entrance into the higher world of knowledge which comprehends mankind but which mankind cannot comprehend"). You said "the only way i really know of to define it is by making some of it, or finding some of it to listen to. then you can go, "ah, that's music. i think"" .... But if music is in the eye (or ear) of the beholder... where does that leave the composer/creator/performer? If someone makes something that they personally intended to be music, then shouldn't it music rather or not you or I (or any other listener) interprets it as such?

why do you keep answering questions about capital letters, or re-linking to pages like how-long-did-it-take-to-make-hotewig.html, if you only answer so few questions? wouldn't it be more efficient to answer more complicated questions that provide new information to people, than reiterating the same answers?

q.a: your analysis is nice but it's not quite the way i meant it. my own analysis of this song is hiding somewhere (actually several places) throughout these questions pages, and is about equal in length to yours
q.q: when i listen to "school" i think it's a deep statement on human nature, and more specifically, ignorance in a depressing way. school is a metaphor for knowledge in general. the lines "i don't wanna go to school, because i'm stupid, i don't want nobody tellin me what to do or how to get through this" to me seem like a statement on how people prefer to figure out life on their own way. they think they can wing it, make it up as they go, improvise. the next lines "i don't want nobody tellin me how to think, tellin me how to sing, tellin me how to do everything" really emphasize this point. but in the next lines, the true intentions behind the narrator's willful ignorance is revealed. "i don't wanna be afraid, of criminals, i don't wanna be afraid, of dangerous politicians" is the climax of the story. he doesn't want to expose himself to the harsh realities of the "real world", which could also be why the song uses the metaphor "school", since students are ofte n warned about said "real world". "i don't wanna be afraid of you, or of me, or the truth" further this point, because scariness is everywhere, and we all wish it wasn't like that, but we know deep inside of us that it is. the last lines, "said that girl made me feel blue, cause she told me I should stay in school, said that girl made me feel blue, don't go to school" is a nice closer, in which the narrator turns his nose to people telling him to "stay informed" or even perhaps "grow up", because all it does is make people sad. do you think this analysis is appropriate? or am i overthinking just a really catchy, danceable song? love your videos, ants just crawled out of my laptop.

q.a: back at that time, california was known to be one of the most forward leaning states on marijuana laws. i think it was only medical by then, but they were one of the first. they were also known to be one of the most forward leaning on gay marriage, which is why the last line of the song got thrown in as well. as for the other states mentioned, there is no truth there whatsoever. alabama was known at the time to have some of the strictest marijuana laws of any state, perhaps still. the remainder of the states were chosen based on the fact that they are 3 syllables and sounded right in the song. over the years since the song was written, legalization of both marijuana and gay marriage have been sweeping the nation, and each time i think to myself 'oh no, i guess that california song probably won't make sense anymore.' but it was never entirely factual to begin with, so the additional inaccuracies make for a nice twist

q.a: i do understand the reference. it's a reference to one of my videos, 'shaving my piano.' a lot of people ask me serious logistical questions about actually shaving a piano, how to do it, how often to do it, what to use, etc... and my response is that it doesn't make sense. shaving a piano doesn't make sense, and is impossible. i did many other videos in 2014 in a similar format, acting out a simple yet illogical task, with physical and musical conviction. i think this was a fertile source of fun short videos, many of which caught on very well with viewers. i hope that makes sense
